item.title: The 'Super-K' flu variant is spreading in Australia. Here's what makes it 'unusual'
item.description: The 'Super-K' flu — otherwise known as the subclade-K variant — is spreading around the globe, including Australia.

item.title: No, you can't transfer your prize, Nobel body says amid Machado's Trump suggestion
item.description: The organisation that oversees the Nobel Peace Prize has thrown cold water on talk of the Venezuelan opposition leader giving her award to Donald Trump.

item.title: Board members, chair quit from Adelaide Festival as fallout from dropped author grows
item.description: SBS News can confirm three board members have now resigned from the Adelaide Festival, amid growing controversy over a decision to drop a Palestinian Australian author and academic.

item.title: Population growth, fertility rates and migration. What could Australia look like in 2035?
item.description: A new report shows which areas of Australia will record the biggest population increases in the years ahead.

item.title: Nationwide protests against ICE sweep across United States
item.description: At least 29 people have been arrested in Minneapolis during ongoing protests over the fatal shooting of a US citizen by an Immigration and Customs Enforcement agent. The killing of Renee Good has sparked demonstrations across the country, while further confrontations with ICE agents have been filmed.

item.title: Cuba defiant after Trump says to 'make a deal, before it is too late'
item.description: Donald Trump has warned Cuba will no longer receive Venezuelan oil or funds, increasing US pressure on the island nation.

item.title: 'Big bill' for taxpayers but cheaper for patients: Wegovy to be subsidised, says minister
item.description: It's going to cost taxpayers a lot of money — but the federal government says subsidising weight loss drug Wegovy is an equity issue, not just a health issue.

item.title: Revealed: Where Australians are paying the most (and least) to see a doctor
item.description: Thousands of medical clinics across the country were contacted for a new report. Here's what it found.

item.title: US federal reserve threatened with criminal charges by Trump administration, bank chair says
item.description: Donald Trump has consistently pressured Jerome Powell and the central bank to move faster in lowering interest rates.

item.title: Jerome Powell facing criminal probe and implications for markets
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Kyle Rodda from capital.com about the day's market action including implications of the US Adminstration's threat to lob criminal charges against Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell as he stands firm on interest rate policy.

item.title: Ardern withdraws from Writers' Week; Adelaide Festival board faces fresh questions
item.description: Former NZ prime minister pulls out of event. Meanwhile, a past Writers' Week director has questioned the Adelaide Festival board's viability after resignations.

item.title: Trump says Iran wants to negotiate as nearly 650 dead in protests
item.description: US-based rights group HRANA said by late Monday it had verified the deaths of 646 people, including 505 protesters.

item.title: Kevin Rudd steps down as Australia's ambassador to the US
item.description: Kevin Rudd will end his tenure as Australia's ambassador to the US a year early following a tumultuous period under the Trump administration.

item.title: Albanese declares national day of mourning for Bondi victims
item.description: It will be observed on 22 January, with the theme determined by a Sydney rabbi whose son-in-law was killed in the terror attack.

item.title: Louise Adler resigns as Adelaide Writers' Week director amid escalating festival crisis
item.description: Randa Abdel-Fattah, the author whose removal from Writers' Week has sparked a backlash, said Adler's resignation is "a tragedy".

item.title: Autism Barbie is unboxed, to mixed reaction from advocates
item.description: Autism advocates have had mixed reactions to the release of an autism Barbie, designed to increase awareness and acceptance of neurodiversity in children, particularly girls. American toymaker Mattel announced the new doll this week, including special features to accomodate the traits and behaviours associated with autism.

item.title: SBS News In Easy English 13 January 2026
item.description: A daily 5 minute news bulletin for English learners and people with a disability.

item.title: Eight key changes in Labor's sweeping hate speech and gun laws
item.description: New offences and penalties could target individuals, including religious leaders, who incite hatred or division. Here are eight changes being proposed.

item.title: Abdel-Fattah rejects Adelaide Festival board apology following writers' week cancellation
item.description: Randa Abdel-Fattah has rejected the Adelaide Festival board's apology for removing her from their line-up, calling it 'disingenuous'.

item.title: 'I see nightmares': Iran's move that's created a 'graveyard of the living' amid protests
item.description: Amid more than two weeks of protests in Iran, members of the Iranian diaspora in Australia have expressed concern for their loved ones.

item.title: Renowned author accused of engaging with paedophiles, sharing child abuse material
item.description: Craig Silvey has been charged with possessing and distributing child exploitation material between 7 and 9 of January.

item.title: Renowned author accused of engaging with paedophiles, sharing child abuse material
item.description: Craig Silvey has been charged with possessing and distributing child exploitation material between 7 and 9 of January.

item.title: Global markets and precious metals hit record high despite Powell investigation
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Kai Chen from MPC Markets about why US, Japanese and German markets are hitting record highs despite the US Administration's investigation into Jerome Powell, plus Matthew Hassan from Westpac on consumer sentiment.

item.title: The secret my dad kept was meant to protect me — it still broke my heart
item.description: Irene was just a few weeks from giving birth when she uncovered a timely secret about her dad, who lived on the other side of the world.

item.title: 'Unsafe' and 'unfairly scrutinised': How the Bondi terror attack changed Australia
item.description: The massacre during a Jewish Hanukkah festival — and its aftermath — have made indelible impacts on the country.

item.title: Donald Trump tells Iranians to keep protesting, says 'help is on its way'
item.description: An Iranian official confirmed that around 2,000 people had been killed in the protests, the first time authorities have given an overall death toll.

item.title: Parents 'under pressure': The cost of educating children in Australia revealed
item.description: Nearly half of the parents surveyed said they are considering having fewer children because of the cost of raising and educating them.

item.title: SA premier responds after Randa Abdel-Fattah threatens defamation action
item.description: Premier unaware whether a concerns notice from Randa Abdel-Fattah has been received, after remarks she calls a "vicious personal assault".

item.title: How does Australia compare? New passport power rankings revealed
item.description: New global rankings reveal which passports offer the greatest travel freedom — and where Australia sits compared with the rest of the world.

item.title: Author threatens to sue South Australia's premier for defamation | SBS News in Easy English 14 January 2026
item.description: A daily news bulletin for English learners and people with a disability.

item.title: Iran's diaspora desperate to hear word from family as communications blackout persists
item.description: Iran’s nationwide communications blackout has entered its second week, severely limiting access to real-time information about the deadly crackdown on anti-government protesters. Iranian authorities have warned that those taking part in the protests could face the death penalty, as reports suggest the death toll has risen to around 2,000. Meanwhile, U.S. President Donald Trump has urged Iranians to continue protesting against the country’s leadership, telling demonstrators that “help is on its way.”

item.title: Global central bankers show support for US Fed Chair Jerome Powell
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Hebe Chen from Vantage Australia about the day's sharemarket action including the significance of a joint statement released by a dozen global central bankers, including the RBA's Michele Bullock, supporting US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell, who is under investigation by the US administration.

item.title: Bondi attack prompts possible 15-year jail terms for hate group members
item.description: People who join or support government-designated hate groups will face 15 years jail, under new legislation in response to the Bondi terror attack. Some Coalition MPs have already voiced concern about the laws' impact on freedom of speech - while one prominent extremist group has announced it will disband.

item.title: Trump's Iran endgame: What 'winning' could look like
item.description: The US president says he wants to "win" in Iran. As rhetoric escalates, experts question what that means — and whether military action looms.

item.title: What would you do if you lost your job? Acclaimed director's new film has a dark answer
item.description: When your job defines you, losing it can have deadly consequences. At least that's the case in Park Chan-wook's thriller No Other Choice.

item.title: Causing cancer and disrupting hormones? The dangerous myths online about sunscreen
item.description: Online fears about sunscreen are popping up, but the science remains unchanged: it’s safe and protective. Here's what we know.

item.title: Trump says he's been told 'killing in Iran is stopping' as US pulls troops from Middle East
item.description: Donald Trump has openly threatened to intervene in Iran for days, without giving specifics.

item.title: Trump says he's been told 'killing in Iran is stopping' as US pulls troops from Middle East
item.description: Donald Trump has openly threatened to intervene in Iran for days, without giving specifics.

item.title: Adelaide Festival retracts statement on Randa Abdel-Fattah, invites her to next writers' week
item.description: The Palestinian Australian author said she is considering the invitation to next year's event, after organisers said they apologised "unreservedly".

item.title: Warnings for Australian travellers to the Middle East, as Iran reopens airspace
item.description: Travellers to countries surrounding Iran have been warned about the risk of "regional conflict, missiles and drones".

item.title: Trade off: major divisions ahead of the signing of the historic Mercosur trade deal
item.description: It's being heralded as one of the biggest trade deals in history, with the EU and some Latin American nations poised to sign the Mercosur Agreement this weekend. Designed in part to reduce reliance on the United States and China and find new growth markets, the deal has attracted strong opposition from some European countries and industries.

item.title: Labor's hate speech laws on the brink as Coalition raises doubts and Greens reject plan
item.description: With the Coalition and Greens taking a swipe at the bill, questions exist over how the government could pass hate speech reform.

item.title: US stops processing immigrant visa applications from 75 countries | SBS News In Easy English 15 January 2026
item.description: A daily 5 minute news bulletin for English learners and people with a disability.

item.title: Climate report warns of increasingly extreme weather
item.description: The European Union's latest annual climate report reveals last year was the world's third-hottest on record. The report also finds the global three-year average has warmed by more than 1.5 degrees Celsius for the first time, a threshold scientists warn dramatically increases the risk of extreme weather events. Climate experts say while the findings are troubling, China and India have made notable improvements in reducing emissions.

item.title: The plan to tackle Australia's drowning crisis
item.description: Since the start of summer, 33 people have lost their lives to drowning in Australia. With drowning trending upwards since the COVID-19 Pandemic, the Australian Water Safety Council has released a new Australian Water Safety Strategy 2030, strengthening national efforts to reduce drowning deaths by 50 per cent by the end of the decade.

item.title: Iran’s brutal crackdown, Trump greases oil execs for Venezuela & Indonesia’s onion repeal
item.description: Can the economy-driven protests in Iran bring down the regime? Plus, the Venezuelan oil games continue as President Trump declares his global power answers to just one thing (hint: it’s not the UN or God), and why illegal importers are dicing with danger in Indonesia.

item.title: 'Fighter's chance': Australian woman to set sail for Gaza on Global Sumud flotilla again
item.description: Juliet Lamont hopes to bring aid into Gaza by sea. The last time she tried, she was detained by Israel.

item.title: BHP challenging for CBA's crown & why US rates may not fall
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Chris Weston from Pepperstone as BHP edges closer to becoming Australia's largest listed company and finds out why he thinks US interest rates may not fall this year.

item.title: 'Descended into madness': A rare message from inside Iran lays bare an activist's fear
item.description: SBS News has spoken to a protester in Iran, describing authorities shooting at civilians amid the country's internet blackout.

item.title: 'Huge achievement': Labor hails wave of under-16 social media account deletions, restrictions
item.description: While the government has welcomed the new data, an expert cautions that it's unclear how many under-16s have stopped using social media.

item.title: Neo-Nazi groups say they're disbanding but this may not be their end, experts say
item.description: Proposed hate laws may disrupt neo-Nazi groups, but experts warn the threat could persist even if the legislation passes.

item.title: Trump says Iran protests easing but won't rule out military strikes
item.description: US President Donald Trump says Iran's crackdown on protests appears to be easing, amid reports a detained protester will avoid the death penalty.

item.title: 'Very generous of her': Wong praises Machado for gifting Nobel prize to Trump
item.description: The foreign minister made the comments after she was asked if the US was creating a world order in which "might was right".

item.title: Antidepressants didn't work for Alexis — she's not alone
item.description: A landmark Australian study has found people living with atypical depression are less likely to respond to medication.

item.title: 'It feels like fascism': Minnesota residents say they won't be bullied by President Trump
item.description: US President Donald Trump has threatened to invoke the Insurrection Act and deploy troops to quell protests against Immigration and Customs Enforcement officers in Minneapolis. Tensions have flared in the city after a federal officer shot and wounded a Venezuelan man during an attempted arrest.

item.title: ICE shootings and Trump's threat to 'insurrectionists': Unrest in Minnesota, explained
item.description: Trump threatens to deploy troops to Minnesota as protests erupt over federal immigration operations and a second officer-involved shooting.

item.title: President Trump meets with Venezuelan opposition leader | SBS News In Easy English 16 January 2026
item.description: A daily 5 minute news bulletin for English learners and people with a disability.

item.title: Why are women worried about their financial future?
item.description: There's a stark gender divide in retirement confidence, with new research from AMP revealing only two in five Australian women feel secure about their financial future, compared to three in five men. The gap is widest among single and divorced women in their 40s, who are often juggling work, children and ageing parents. For more, Stephanie Youssef spoke with AMP’s Director of Growth and Customer Solutions, Julie Slapp.

item.title: INTERVIEW: How is the social media ban working and is it an effective measure?
item.description: It's been just over a month since the government enacted its world-first social media ban for those aged under 16 years old. The government says they have deactivated, removed or restricted 4.7 million accounts so far. But what does this figure mean, and is an outright ban the most effective method for mitigating young people's exposure to harmful content online? In this episode of Weekend One on One Catriona Stirrat speaks to Nicholas Carah - Director of the Center for Digital Cultures and Societies at the University of Queensland.

item.title: ASX hits 11 week high
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Isaac Poole from Oreana Private Wealth as the Australian sharemarket hits a record high, despite a growing divergence of opnion on the direction of US interest rates.

item.title: 'Someone out there cares': When fires raged, a Melbourne baker opened his doors
item.description: As fires displace thousands in Victoria, a Melbourne baker draws on his refugee past to help evacuees and emergency service volunteers.

item.title: How did Australia's 'most liveable' capital city become the most affordable for renting a house?
item.description: Only one capital city in Australia has seen the cost of renting a house go down over the last 12 months.

item.title: Asian-Inspired coffees gain ground in Australia
item.description: Australia is known worldwide for its strong coffee culture. But across major cities, new styles blending Asian flavours with more familiar brews are quietly reshaping café menus.

item.title: INTERVIEW: Loneliness - the hidden health danger
item.description: A lot of people already identify or know the problems from smoking and what it can do for your health, but not a lot of people understand that loneliness or social isolation carries around the same health risks of smoking up to 15 cigarettes a day. Tyler Prochnow is an assistant professor at Texas A&M at their School of Public Health and an expert in social connectedness, physical activity and mental health.

item.title: Donald Trump appoints Tony Blair, Marco Rubio and more to Gaza 'board of peace'
item.description: The group will supervise the temporary governance of Gaza, under a US plan.

item.title: She's a 'crazy pigeon lady'. He wants to revive a dying sport. This bird is their obsession
item.description: Your perception of pigeons is wrong, these Australians say. Their lives revolve around them — but their worlds couldn't be more different.

item.title: Government to separate gun laws, drop racial vilification from sweeping reform bill
item.description: It comes after the Greens announced it would back the gun law reforms but refused to support the bill's other proposals.

item.title: How much for a coffee? New drinks are pushing prices to $8 or more
item.description: Classic coffee styles continue to dominate sales, but a new trend reflects a wider shift in tastes shaped by Australia's increasingly diverse population.

item.title: Government splits hate speech and gun laws in bid to save Bondi reforms
item.description: The Albanese government has amended its proposed response to the Bondi Beach shootings, splitting its wide-ranging hate speech and gun reform package in two in a bid to secure passage through Parliament. Facing resistance from both the Coalition and the Greens over the breadth and rushed nature of the laws, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has made changes in hopes of receiving support from both political groups to pass each set of reforms.

item.title: Darren lengthened his legs to be taller. Now he walks with a limp
item.description: More people than ever before are making themselves taller with surgery. But while this can improve lives, some are left with long-term problems.

item.title: Australia's 'most liveable' city is now the cheapest to rent houses
item.description: The housing crisis has seen people finding it increasingly hard to rent or buy a house in Australia's capital cities. But while most of the country has seen prices going up there's one place where prices have gone down - and that's Melbourne, where rental prices have gone down almost two percent year on year. SBS's Cameron Carr spoke to Dr Nicola Powell from Domain, to find out what's driving down prices.

item.title: 'Full solidarity': European countries react after Trump's tariff announcement over Greenland
item.description: The countries named by Trump have backed Denmark, warning that the US' plans could collapse the NATO military alliance.

item.title: From lifeline to 'existential crisis': The high human cost of Victoria's public housing overhaul
item.description: In the middle of a housing and cost-of-living crisis, the Victorian government is in the process of demolishing all 44 of Melbourne's public housing towers. Despite significant pushback and a parliamentary inquiry calling for an immediate halt to works, the Victorian government is pushing ahead with the plans.

item.title: Iran's leader says 'several thousand' killed during anti-regime protests
item.description: Human rights groups say more than 3,000 people have been killed and more than 20,000 arrested during the demonstratoins.

item.title: Thinking of changing your career this year? Consider these five steps before you do
item.description: Between a shrinking job market, redundancies, and the threat of AI, changing careers in 2026 is different from how it used to be.

item.title: 'Worrying moment': Can Trump use tariffs to force a Greenland deal under international law?
item.description: In his bid to control the autonomous Danish territory, Trump has vowed to hit European allies with additional levies.

item.title: South Australian premier's push for Adelaide Festival to drop Abdel-Fattah revealed in letter
item.description: A newly published letter shows how the South Australian premier argued for Randa Abdel-Fattah to be dropped from Adelaide Writers' Week.

item.title: I was a single parent just trying to survive. Then a new hobby changed everything
item.description: Rather than being at home, Bridget Hallam always wanted to be "out in the world, living life". Then she found a way to do that.

item.title: Why Albanese's new hate speech laws were always going to face an uphill battle
item.description: Labor has dropped racial vilification offences from its hate speech proposals. It's not the first time such a bid has failed.

item.title: Man in critical condition after Sydney's third shark attack in two days
item.description: Paramedics are treating a man who has become the third Sydney shark attack victim in two days after one escaped with his life and another boy was hospitalised.

item.title: Australia considers invitation to join Trump's 'Board of Peace' as world leaders react cautiously
item.description: Initially established to oversee the future governance and reconstruction of Gaza, a draft charter suggests it would then expand.

item.title: Starmer tells Trump it's 'wrong' to impose tariffs on European allies over Greenland
item.description: Donald Trump and his administration have argued that Greenland coming under US rule would serve American "national security".

item.title: $17.4 billion a year: As the rich get richer, could a wealth tax disrupt the 'vicious cycle'?
item.description: New Oxfam analysis found that Australian billionaires' wealth grew by almost $600,000 a day in the last year.

item.title: 'Tomorrow or nothing?': PM issues ultimatum over Bondi reforms as parliament returns
item.description: The prime minister has urged the Opposition explain "walking away" from hate speech laws recommended by the antisemitism envoy.

item.title: Europe toughens stance as Trump threatens new tariffs over Greenland
item.description: European leaders have condemned threats levelled by the United States to impose new tariffs on countries who don't cooperate with US ambitions to take over Greenland. US President Donald Trump has continued with his plans to acquire control of the Arctic island, prompting warnings about the future of NATO and transatlantic ties.

item.title: Parliament to debate legislation on gun reform and hate speech | SBS News In Easy English 19 January 2026
item.description: A daily 5 minute news bulletin for English learners and people with a disability.

item.title: What's inside the government's gun reform bill? And why elements are 'a recipe for disaster'
item.description: While gun reforms may provide "a sense of comfort" for some, critics argue everyday Australians will bear the cost and scrutiny of the changes.

item.title: What we know about the 'Board of Peace' Donald Trump has asked Australia to join
item.description: Australia is "respectfully considering" its invitation to the board, which has a wide-ranging remit.

item.title: Teens' social media ban opens door for new experiences
item.description: .The government's world-first social media ban has been in place for just over a month, coinciding with Australia's school holidays. There are conflicting perspectives between the government, social media experts and young people on how effectively the ban has been implemented so far. But with less or no access to social media, how are young people spending their spare time?

item.title: Why Trump's Europe tariff threat could backfire & China's record low birthrate
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with David Bassanese from Betashares about Donald Trump's latest threats to try and purchase Greenland and finds out why it could backfire; plus the day on the sharemarket including a look at China's economy as its birthrate falls to a record low with David Walsh from Sarto Advisory Pty Ltd.

item.title: Is NATO dead in the water? Experts say the once-strong alliance is now 'limping on'
item.description: US-Europe relations have been deteriorating, threatening NATO and leaving Australia in an awkward position.

item.title: Trump links Greenland push to Nobel snub, says he will '100 per cent' follow through on tariff threats
item.description: EU leaders are holding an emergency summit on Thursday to discuss their response to one of the gravest crises in years to hit transatlantic ties.

item.title: Four shark attacks in 48 hours: Governments pressured to act, as swimmers told to visit pools
item.description: Four separate shark bites in three days have forced a string of beaches to be closed.

item.title: Four shark attacks in 48 hours: Governments pressured to act, as swimmers told to visit pools
item.description: Four separate shark bites in three days have forced a string of beaches to be closed.

item.title: 'A true maestro': Tributes pour in after Italian designer Valentino dies aged 93
item.description: Known for dressing style icons from Jackie Kennedy to Audrey Hepburn, Valentino Garavani is being remembered as a master of elegance.

item.title: Three shark attacks in two days - experts warn of dangerous conditions
item.description: A man is in a critical condition after the third shark attack at a Sydney beach in less than 48 hours. It follows attacks on Monday and Sunday, in which an 11 -year-old boy's surfboard was bitten by a shark and a 12-year-old boy was critically injured and remains in hospital.

item.title: NSW shark attacks: How can you swim safely and avoid a shark bite?
item.description: Experts say murky waters are prime conditions for shark attacks.

item.title: Coalition divided over hate laws despite Liberal 'fixes', as Greens flag free speech concerns
item.description: Labor's anti-hate laws are expected to pass after securing crucial Liberal support, which Sussan Ley says has "fixed" the bill.

item.description: Labor's anti-hate laws are expected to pass after securing crucial Liberal support, which Sussan Ley says has "fixed" the bill.

item.description: A daily 5 minute news bulletin for English learners and people with a disability.

item.title: Bob Katter recognises Middle Eastern heritage, months after threatening reporter about it
item.description: Months after raising his fist at a journalist, Bob Katter has acknowledged that his grandfather migrated from the Middle East.

item.title: 'Should take it seriously': Warning for Australia as Trump faces EU trade backlash
item.description: Experts have told SBS News that Trump's latest tariffs could lead to a global trade war and economic upheaval.

item.title: Tariff threats trigger market volatility & BHP's record copper and iron ore production
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Julie Lee from FTSE Russell about the day's market action including how the market is dealing with Donald Trump's latest tariff threats and why investors didn't like BHP's record copper and iron ore production report.

item.title: Jewish teens left shaken by alleged antisemitic attack, police say
item.description: A group of Orthodox Jewish teenagers were pursued by a driver allegedly yelling antisemitic abuse, Victoria Police said on Tuesday.

item.title: Gun control, anti-hate laws pass the Lower House
item.description: New gun control and anti-hate laws have passed the lower house of parliament in response to the Bondi terror attack at a Jewish festival, which killed 15 people last month. They are expected to pass into law, but the process has been far from harmonious.

item.title: A fourth shark attack prompts more beach closures
item.description: Following a period of heavy rain, a spate of suspected Bull shark attacks in New South Wales has left beach goers on edge. On Tuesday, a man was attacked by shark at Point Plomer beach near Port Macquarie on the state's Mid North Coast, escaping with only minor injuries. This is the fourth shark attacks in New South Wales over just two days.

item.title: Japan will head for a snap election
item.description: Japan's Prime Minister has announced plans to dissolve the parliament and trigger a snap election in less than three weeks. Sanae Takaichi is hoping to capitalise on her surging public opinion ratings. But facing mounting challenges at home and abroad, analysts say it is a risky strategy.

item.title: $1.5 billion for a seat: Is Trump's new Board of Peace an 'irreparable' threat?
item.description: Experts say Trump's new body is susceptible to nepotism and corruption, and could undermine the role of the United Nations.

item.title: Macron warns of 'world without rules' after Trump shares texts from European leaders
item.description: Emmanuel Macron said France preferred "respect to bullies" and rejected "unacceptable" tariffs.

item.title: Labor's hate speech laws pass parliament in late-night vote
item.description: The federal government has struck a last-minute deal with the Liberals to pass contentious new laws targeting hate groups.

item.title: 'A pioneer and an inspiration': Marie Bashir, NSW's first female governor, dies aged 95
item.description: Dame Marie Bashir is being remembered for a lifetime of service after her death at the age of 95.

item.title: Nationals trio quit positions after defying Sussan Ley over hate laws
item.description: The Opposition leader has accepted the resignations of three Coalition cabinet members, who crossed the floor over hate laws.

item.title: What is the Chagos Islands deal, and why has Trump accused the UK of 'stupidity'?
item.description: The UK agreed to hand the Chagos Islands to Mauritius in a deal that the Trump administration previously backed.

item.title: The new United Nations? What to know about Donald Trump's 'Board of Peace'
item.description: United States President Donald Trump has invited world leaders to join his so-called 'Board of Peace'. Conceived with a mandate to oversee the administration and reconstruction of Gaza, the plan has quickly ballooned in its planned remit.

item.title: Labor shuts down future race hate laws after late night Senate vote
item.description: .The government has suggested further measures to combat hate speech are unlikely to be pursued, even if a royal commission into antisemitism calls for stronger laws. It follows the passage of two separate bills - on gun reform and hate speech - becoming law after final approval by the Senate on Tuesday night.

item.title: Hate crimes reforms pass parliament | SBS News In Easy English 21 January 2026
item.description: A daily 5-minute news bulletin for English learners and people with a disability.

item.title: Marie Bashir - 'a tremendous role model'
item.description: New South Wales' first female governor, Dame Marie Bashir, has died aged 95. Prime Minister Anthony Albanese and New South Wales Premier Chris Minns are among those to have paid tribute to Dame Marie's life and legacy as a respected public servant, and committed advocate across mental health, education, Indigenous rights, and social inclusion.

item.title: Family 'shattered' by Canadian backpacker's death on holiday in Australia
item.description: The devastated family of 19-year-old Piper James is waiting for news on the cause of her death.

item.title: 'This should be good news': The koala success story with a catch
item.description: Koala numbers in some areas are "concerning" researchers, who predict populations could become unsustainable.

item.title: Global markets slide on Trump's Europe tariff concerns
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Scott Phillips from The Motley Fool about the day's market action including why investors are concerned about Trump's latest threats, gold's new record and why BHP is edging closer to becoming Australia's largest listed company.

item.title: Study finds greater numbers of warrantless searches in multicultural communities
item.description: A new study reveals that communities with multi-racial backgrounds are exposed to warrantless searches up to three-and-a-half times more than communities in white-majority areas. According to the analysis of Victoria Police's use of extraordinary search power, this happens even when areas of white-majority communities have higher crime rates.

item.title: 'We sit by ourselves': Littleproud confirms Coalition split after mass Nationals resignation
item.description: Eight Nationals frontbenchers have quit the shadow cabinet in protest following the resignation of three of their colleagues.

item.title: 'We sit by ourselves': Littleproud confirms Coalition split after mass Nationals resignation
item.description: Eight Nationals frontbenchers have quit the shadow cabinet in protest following the resignation of three of their colleagues.

item.title: Who's richest? Australia's 'great wealth transfer' is reshaping the ladder
item.description: The boomer-gen X net worth gap narrows as younger Australians experience a boom in average household wealth, new analysis suggests.

item.title: Kenedi made almost $300k as a surrogate overseas. Should Australians also be paid?
item.description: Some experts believe Australian surrogacy laws are ineffective and lead many couples desperate to start a family to seek options overseas.

item.title: Nationals quit the shadow cabinet over hate speech laws | Morning News Bulletin 22 January 2026
item.description: The Coalition faces another split as all Nationals MPs resign from the shadow cabinet; Donald Trump says he won't take Greenland by force, in a speech to world leaders; Alex de Minaur advances to the Australian Open's third round.

item.title: Trump says US has reached a deal with NATO on Greenland framework
item.description: NATO says talks between Denmark, Greenland and the US will aim to ensure that Russia and China never gain a foothold in Greenland.

item.title: 'Grief with no ending': Australia holds day of mourning to remember Bondi victims
item.description: It is the first time Australia has observed a national day of mourning since the death of Queen Elizabeth II in 2022.

item.title: 'Doomsday scenario': Death toll in Pakistan mall fire climbs to around 50 people
item.description: The inferno is Karachi's largest fire in more than a decade.

item.title: 'Doomsday scenario': Death toll in Pakistan mall fire climbs to around 50 people
item.description: The inferno is Karachi's largest fire in more than a decade.

item.title: Melbourne mayor condemns vandalism of 150-year-old colonial monuments
item.description: Pioneer Monument and Separation Memorial in Melbourne's Flagstaff Gardens have been vandalised ahead of Australia Day.

item.title: NATO members weigh up response to Trump's plans for Greenland | Midday News Bulletin 22 January 2026
item.description: NATO members weigh up their response to Donald Trump's plans for Greenland; the future of the National-Liberal Coalition partnership in jeopardy after mass resignations; and in basketball, former NBL player AJ Ogilvy has publicly revealed he is gay.

item.title: Europe's not heading in the right direction: Trump
item.description: The US President has attacked his European allies at the World Economic Forum in Davos for their ongoing refusal to let the United States takeover Greenland. His 70-minute speech also took broad aim at the continent for other things Donald Trump believes Europe is doing ‘wrong’. His remarks had been widely anticipated amid ongoing tensions over the Arctic Island.

item.title: Turnbull says Coalition a 'smouldering wreckage' as Joyce takes aim at Littleproud
item.description: Sussan Ley has been trying to keep the Coalition together since its temporary split after the 2025 federal election.

item.title: President Trump says his Board of Peace is 'the greatest board ever formed'
item.description: Saudi Arabia, Turkiye, Egypt, Jordan, Indonesia, Pakistan and Qatar have accepted US President Donald Trump's invitation to join the so-called 'Board of Peace.' Israel's Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has also publicly confirmed Israel's participation, while Vladimir Putin says he's considering Trump's invitation to join. Amid concerns the board of peace will pose a threat to the United Nations, the UN Secretary General has urged continued commitment to international law.

item.title: Donald Trump says he has negotiated a framework on Greenland | SBS News In Easy English 22 January 2026
item.description: A daily 5-minute news bulletin for English learners and people with a disability.

item.title: Major search continues for missing people after landslide at New Zealand holiday park
item.description: Two people have died in a separate landslide, as the North Island reels from a spate of wild weather.

item.title: Major search continues for missing people after landslide at New Zealand holiday park
item.description: Two people have died in a separate landslide, as the North Island reels from a spate of wild weather.

item.title: Australia reflects, on this National Day of Mourning
item.description: Australians are paying their respects to the 15 victims of a Bondi terror attack on December 14 during a National Day of Mourning. The Prime Minister and Opposition leader are calling on all Australians to reflect upon the tragic events and stand in solidarity with the Jewish Community.

item.title: 'Existential moment': After a second split, is it game over for the Coalition?
item.description: Experts say the new anti-hate laws may not be the only reason behind the recent Coalition split, with Nationals being "really worried" about losing voters.

item.title: Jim Chalmers: 'The Coalition is a smoking ruin'
item.description: The Coalition has reached a breaking point as the National Party officially splits from the Liberals, following a mass frontbench walkout over controversial hate speech legislation. While Opposition Leader Sussan Ley attempted to block some of the resignations to maintain unity, former colleagues and political rivals alike are labeling the fallout a "smoking ruin" that threatens the future of the alternative government.

item.title: National day of mourning for victims of Bondi attack | Evening News Bulletin 22 January 2026
item.description: Australians mark a national day of mourning for victims of the Bondi terror attack; Greenlanders react to Donald Trump's claim of a deal struck with NATO on Greenland; and in cycling, the manager of Tour de France champion Tadej Pogacar to visit Adelaide for the Tour Down Under.

item.title: Up to 48C: Parts of Australia to approach 'possible record-breaking heat', BoM says
item.description: Forecasts show parts of south-east Australia will swelter under a record-breaking heatwave next week.

item.title: Cars lifted from ocean in recovery mission after flash floods
item.description: A helicopter retrieved destroyed cars that were washed out to sea by flash floods in Victoria last week.

item.title: Trump’s Greenland U-turn, Syria clashes force Kurds into retreat & China ‘brings home the bacon’
item.description: Is Donald Trump’s retreat from tariffs and military threats over Greenland - a NATO reset or a tactical pause? Syria edges toward reunification but at a major cost to the Kurds – and IS group fighters escape. Plus how a farm girl’s plea from rural China went hog-wild online.

item.title: Police investigate how alleged NSW shooter accessed gun, confirm pregnant woman killed
item.description: Police said the alleged shooter was granted bail with strict conditions over domestic violence charges.

item.title: Police investigate how alleged NSW shooter accessed gun, confirm pregnant woman killed
item.description: Police said the alleged shooter was granted bail with strict conditions over domestic violence charges.

item.title: Surprise jobs report boosts chance of February rate rise
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Johnathan McMenamin from Barrenjoey and Adam Dawes from Shaw and Parnters as Australia's unemployment rate falls from 4.3% to 4.1% in December increasing the chance of an interest rate rise in a fortnight.

item.title: 'Profoundly sorry': Albanese apologises to Bondi attack victims' loved ones
item.description: The prime minister has spoken at the national day of mourning memorial at the Sydney Opera House.

item.title: Australia Day 2026: Here’s what's open over the long weekend
item.description: Most shops will be open but in some states they are subject to restricted hours. In one state car and boat dealerships will close.

item.title: 'Left out and ostracised': The social media ban's uneven execution — and other effects
item.description: It's been six weeks since Australians under 16 were banned from most social media platforms. What impact has the ban had?

item.title: Three shot dead and suspects still not apprehended | Morning News Bulletin 23 January 2026
item.description: Three people shot dead in regional New South Wales with suspects still not apprehended; Ukraine's leader calls out Europe for inaction after meeting with the US President; And in tennis, Novak Djokovic defeats Italian qualifier Francesco Maestrelli in straight sets.

item.title: Australian summer is undergoing a 'total transformation', scientists warn
item.description: Scientists say climate change made this summer's blistering heatwave five times more likely and cities need to adapt urgently.

item.title: Strong jobs data sparks warning of fresh rate rise within weeks
US officially withdraws from the World Health Organization
item.description: Global health experts said the withdrawal poses risks for the US, the WHO and the world.

item.title: Ley confident in leadership as Albanese says she was 'undermined from day one'
item.description: The prime minister said he had "given up worrying about what happens" within the Coalition.

item.title: 'We were all screaming': Rose Byrne and Jacob Elordi receive first Oscar nominations
item.description: Rose Byrne's performance in If I Had Legs I'd Kick You has already earned four key pre-Oscars awards, including a Golden Globe.

item.title: Sussan Ley says she is confident she will remain Liberals leader | Midday News Bulletin 23 January 2026
item.description: Liberal Party leader Sussan Ley says she is confident she will stay in the job amid fallout from the Coalition split; European leaders hold emergency talks in Brussels to respond to Donald Trump's threats; Australia names its Winter Olympics team, with a record number of female athletes.

item.title: President Trump keeps world leaders on their toes
item.description: .US President Donald Trump has used the World Economic Forum in Davos to push a new security framework for the Arctic, and signal what he says is momentum towards ending the war in Ukraine. The week has also exposed deep divisions among allies over Greenland and Europe’s role in global security.

item.title: Liberals leader Sussan Ley under pressure after Coalition split | SBS News In Easy English 23 January 2026
item.description: A daily 5-minute news bulletin for English learners and people with a disability.

item.title: Liberals leader Sussan Ley under pressure after Coalition split | SBS News In Easy English 23 January 2026
item.description: A daily 5-minute news bulletin for English learners and people with a disability.

item.title: Six people confirmed missing after landslide at New Zealand campground
item.description: Heavy rains triggered the landslide at the holiday park where families were enjoying the school summer holidays.

item.title: 'Disgraceful': Tony Burke condemns threat to Sydney mosque
item.description: NSW Police said it has started an investigation, and there's no ongoing threat to the community.

item.title: The café that’s trained 700 people living with disability and neurodivergence
item.description: The Australian of the Year will be named in four categories on Sunday night. Among them is Emily Briffa, Tasmania's nomination for Local Hero. She's been recognised for her work at social enterprise cafe Hamlet, which trains and employs people with disability, neuro divergence and mental health concerns.

item.title: Up to 100 police officers involved in search for a gunman in NSW town | Evening News Bulletin 23 January 2026
item.description: Up to 100 police officers involved in search for a gunman in NSW town; Donald Trump says a large US military fleet is moving towards Iran; Aryna Sabalenka advances to the fourth round of the Australian Open.

item.title: Australia’s summers being transformed as climate change drives heatwaves
item.description: Australian summers are undergoing what scientists call a "total transformation," with a new study from World Weather Attribution revealing the country can now expect heatwaves every five years on average. The study's researchers say climate change made Australia's blistering heatwave in early January five times more likely, and there's an urgent need for the country to adapt to changed conditions. The warning comes as the country's south-eastern states prepare for what's forecast to be a prolonged, severe heatwave starting this weekend.

item.title: Police search powers declaration 'unlawful', judge rules
item.description: The expanded powers had allowed police to stop and search people in and around the Melbourne CBD without a warrant.

item.title: What next - if anything - for the Coalition?
item.description: The Coalition’s unity has reached a new low following what's being described as a 'terminal' breakdown between key frontbenchers, marking their third significant split since the 2025 election. While leadership maintains that the door remains open for future cooperation, analysts suggest the in-fighting is further alienating a public that is increasingly turning toward minor parties and independent alternatives.

item.title: Is the A$ headed for 70USc?
item.description: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gonçalves speaks with Tony Sycamore from IG Markets about the day's sharemarket action as the Australian dollar and gold price charge towards new milestones.

item.title: Zelenskyy suggested European leaders are weak. Can they stand up to Trump?
item.description: Trump has supposedly secured a decision on Greenland. Experts say specifics are still unclear — though the threats will be remembered.

item.title: Japanese PM Sanae Takaichi dissolves parliament after three months in office
item.description: Japan's first female prime minister has called a snap election, setting the stage for a 12-day campaign.

item.title: Japan's Prime Minister dissolves parliament ahead of snap election | Morning News Bulletin 24 January 2026
item.description: Japan's Prime Minister dissolves parliament ahead of a snap election; millions brace for severe heat over the long weekend; Canadian teen Victoria Mboko advances to a fourth-round match-up with Aryna Sabalenka in the Australian Open.

item.title: Allowed to beg, forbidden to study: Why conditions for Afghan women are worsening
item.description: Despite an injection of more than $260 million in Australian aid, the situation for women in Afghanistan remains 'bleak'.

item.title: 50 years since Concorde's first commercial flight, memories linger on
item.description: The world’s first supersonic passenger plane, Concorde, made its maiden commercial flight 50 years ago this month on 21 January 1976. Its delta-wing design and drooping nose made it instantly recognisable, and although it went out of service in 2003, it is still remembered to this day.

item.title: Rights for women deteriorating four years after Taliban takeover in Afghanistan
item.description: It’s been more than four years since the Taliban took control of Afghanistan - and according to human rights organisations, the situation for women and girls is only getting progressively worse - with a near-total exclusion from most public employment and education. The United Nations has warned the country is expected to remain one of the world’s largest humanitarian crises for the year ahead.

item.title: Aussie survivor through to next round after Naomi Osaka pulls out of Australian Open
item.description: Maddison Inglis, the last remaining home hope in the Australian Open women's draw, will progress to round four after Naomi Osaka pulled out of the tournament.

item.title: After a night out, men and women face very different heart health risks
item.description: Alcohol consumption can lead to a range of health issues, and your risk level can change based on a range of factors.

item.title: Coroner's autopsy on Canadian backpacker points to drowning as cause of death
item.description: The Queensland coroner has found evidence Piper James' death was caused by drowning after her body was found surrounded by several dingoes.

item.title: Do you know where your food is really from? This Australian scientist does
item.description: Millions of people globally fall ill each year, from unsafe or contaminated foods. Some is due to food fraud, the act of purposely selling fake, mis-labelled or substituted food products for financial gain. Australian scientists have developed new ways to combat this multi-billion dollar problem.

item.title: Fighting fakes and food fraud, this team knows where your festive dish really comes from
item.description: Almost five million people in Australia fall ill each year from unsafe or contaminated food. Australian technology is helping combat this growing global problem.

item.title: Autopsy of backpacker finds evidence consistent with drowning | Midday News Bulletin 24 January 2026
item.description: Early autopsy finds evidence consistent with drowning in death of Canadian backpacker in K'gari; suicide bomber kills at least 7 at a wedding in northwest Pakistan; Mitch Marsh to lead host of Australian cricket internationals in The Hundred.

item.title: Heatwave, fires and a cyclone in WA: 'Severe and long-lasting' weather shapes long weekend
item.description: Record-breaking temperatures not seen since the 2019-20 Black Summer bushfires are expected to prevail over the coming week

item.title: Police widen search for triple murder suspect, flag possibility others may be helping him
item.description: NSW Police Assistant Commissioner Andy Holland said there's a "possibility that people are assisting [Julian Ingram] to avoid police apprehension".

item.title: Twelve-year-old boy dies from injuries after Sydney shark attack
item.description: A 12-year-old boy who was bitten by a shark in Sydney's east last week has succumbed to his critical leg injuries.

item.title: 12-year-old mauled by shark last weekend dies | Evening News Bulletin 24 January 2026
item.description: A twelve-year-old attacked by a shark last weekend has died... Turkiye warns Iran that Israel may be seeking a chance to strike, as a US carrier group moves closer... and, in tennis, a great day for American women at the Australian Open.

item.title: Australian veterans, RSL respond to Trump's 'profound insult' of US allies' soldiers
item.description: Australians have joined a chorus of disgust across Europe after Trump said allies' troops had stayed "a little off the front lines" in Afghanistan.

item.title: US federal officers shoot and kill a man in Minneapolis | Morning News Bulletin 25 January 2026
item.description: US federal officers shoot and kill a man in Minneapolis as immigration crackdown continues; Ukraine-Russia talks end without agreement as one killed overnight in Russian strikes on Ukraine; late Mariners equaliser holds Auckland to draw in A-League clash.

item.title: 'They think we're billionaires': This couple inherited a manor. It's been anything but idyllic
item.description: Inheriting property is often complex. When Anne-Sophie and Olivier inherited a 500-year-old château, it presented some unique challenges.

item.title: A century ago, the average Australian was a 24-year-old man. Who is it now?
item.description: Australia celebrates its national day on Monday, but do we really know who we are?

item.title: Sharing and saving the legacy of Japan's Samurai
item.description: Clad in armour and guided by a strict code of honour, Japan’s samurai were more than elite warriors; they were the architects of a society shaped by loyalty, discipline and power. For centuries, these sword-bearing nobles dominated Japan’s battlefields and politics, leaving a legacy that still influences the nation’s culture, values and global image today. The history and culture of Japan's Samurai warriors are being celebrated in a new museum in Tokyo. Visitors can try on armour, hold swords and even have a go at throwing special weapons.

item.title: Tension mounts in Minneapolis after fatal shooting of man who 'cared about people deeply'
item.description: The 37-year-old man is the second civilian to have been fatally shot in Minneapolis since Trump sent immigration enforcement officials to the city.

item.title: A Royal Commission has been called. Now what?
item.description: .After weeks of political pressure, the Prime Minister this month announced a Royal Commission into the rise in antisemitism and factors behind the second-deadliest mass shooting in Australian history. It is the latest of a series of Royal Commissions into wide-ranging issues, but what is a Royal Commission and what does it do?

item.title: Man charged over 'abhorrent' threat to Sydney mosque
item.description: The material posted to Sydney's Lakemba Mosque singled out Muslims, Middle Eastern communities, Indigenous people and left-wing politicians.

item.title: Albanese names 'outstanding' replacement for Rudd as US ambassador
item.description: Anthony Albanese has tapped a defence boss and experienced diplomat for the coveted role in Washington DC.

item.title: Man charged over Australia Day threats to mosque| Midday News Bulletin 25 January 2026
item.description: Man charged over Australia Day threats to a mosque and other groups; US envoy meets with Israeli PM to discuss future of Gaza as three killed in Israeli strikes; Japanese star Naomi Osaka drops out of Australian Open.

item.title: Fires continue to burn as huge swathes of southeast face severe heatwave warnings
item.description: Parts of Australia are bracing for the effects of fire and extreme heat, while others are at risk of flash flooding.

item.title: Police descend on remote town after possible sighting of alleged triple murderer
item.description: A small former mining town in central NSW has become the focus of a police search after a potential sighting of Julian Ingram.

item.title: The Aussie dollar has reached a 15-month high. What does this mean for us?
item.description: A strong Australian dollar could be welcome news for overseas travellers and household budgets.

item.description: Three people arrested over separate hate-related incidents in Sydney, United States envoys urge Israel to enter second phase of ceasefire, Carlos Alcaraz and Jannik Sinner set to dominate at Australian Open.

item.title: Astronaut and three other 'visionaries' rewarded with Australian of the Year Awards
item.description: An astronaut, an ultramarathon runner, a dementia researcher, and an Indigenous construction leader have been recognised for their achievements.
